awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Establishing novel signaling transmission modes of LOV photoreceptors
awd_abstract_narration:
Photoreceptors are complex protein machines that respond to a fundamental sensory input: light. They are found in nearly all organisms and are critical to behavior, circadian rhythms, metabolism, and photosynthesis. Thus, elucidating what they do and how they work (i) informs how organisms from bacteria to humans adapt to environmental changes and sustain life, and (ii) provides design rules for engineering "optogenetic" protein tools for controlling cellular function with light. The overall goal of this CAREER Award is to reveal novel mechanisms and applications of light/oxygen/voltage (LOV) photoreceptor signaling in natural and engineered systems, through a unified research and educational program at the interface of photobiology, synthetic biology, and bioengineering.

This project will establish the signaling function and signal transmission mode of LOV proteins with regulators of G-protein signaling (RGS) as their ontological effectors. The existence of RGS-LOV has been hypothesized based on bioinformatics but never proven by biochemical and biophysical characterization. Preliminary data suggests that the light-driven structural rearrangements unmask a membrane localization sequence, which enhances protein-protein interaction between the RGS and its G-alpha signaling partner to terminate G-protein coupled receptor signaling upon translocation. RGS-LOV structure-function relationships and functional signaling activity will be studied (i) in vitro using purified recombinant protein produced in bacteria and (ii) using cellular assays in heterologously expressing mammalian cells, as assessed by spectroscopy, immunohistochemistry, and high-resolution microscopy. Neither light-induced membrane localization nor the functional separation between regulators of G-proteins and light-gated membrane localization in one protein has been observed among natural LOV proteins. The research will impact broad research communities through the dissemination of optogenetic tools and open-source hardware. Educational activities will extend LOV photobiology studies and application into undergraduate research and STEM training, through activities that focus on hands-on learning and combining wet laboratory experience with mathematical models of biological signaling.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Photosensory proteins are complex machines that respond to a fundamental sensory input: light. They are critical to behavior (e.g. circadian rhythms, phototaxis, phototropism) and metabolism (e.g. photosynthesis). Thus, elucidating their signaling roles and structure-function (i.e. what they do and how they work) inform how organisms adapt to environmental changes and sustain life. Light-oxygen-voltage (LOV) flavoproteins comprise the most ubiquitous class of photoreceptors, and they are of fundamental importance to optogenetic approaches to understanding cellular dynamics. The overall goal of this CAREER was to establish novel mechanisms and applications of LOV protein signaling in natural and engineered systems, through a unified research and educational program. 

Research and Educational Activities: We discovered that a class of fungal LOV proteins (RGS-LOV) has a novel photosensory signal transmission mode of dynamic recruitment to the membrane; this process is mediated by a blue-light regulated electrostatic protein-lipid interaction with anionic phospholipids of the cell membrane [1-2]. Studies were primarily performed with BcLOV4 protein from Botrytis cinerea. The inducible recruitment can be used to optogenetically control cell signaling by carrying a fused protein from the cytosol to the membrane [3-7] by single-component operation, i.e. without needing any other protein components. We successfully created a suite of optogenetic tools for Rho-family [3-6] GTPase signaling for inducible control over actin polymerization and the cytoskeleton.  We subsequently found that BcLOV4 has a light-and-temperature dependent response that allows its activation by combining two logical inputs, light and heat [7].  We added to our biophysical understanding of RGS-LOV by finite element modeling (FEM) of the spatial and temporal dynamics of BcLOV4 signaling [8].

For educational activities, we mentored undergraduate teams that built open-source optoelectronics hardware useful for optogenetics and multiplexed absorbance/fluorescence assays. We created an open-source plate reader (OSP) [9-10], a critically important instrument for biological assays/diagnostics, that costs a fraction of commercial systems. The OSP was validated in part by photochemical studies of LOV proteins. Thus, this CAREER married research and education in the biophysics and applications of LOV proteins in one scholarly pursuit. 

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts: The activities had intellectual merits in both LOV photobiology and the open-source hardware or DIY (do-it-yourself) biology movement. RGS-LOVs are the first described natural photoreceptors that signal by dynamic membrane recruitment and/or possess a directly light-regulated protein:membrane interaction. The FEM contributed to an emerging category of models termed bulk-surface models to capture the inherent protein coupling between the 3D cytoplasm (bulk) and 2D membrane (surface); specifically, it applied bulk-surface techniques to unique volumes reconstructed from confocal microscopy stacks of individual cells.  The OSP demonstrated that commercially competitive instrumentation of complex functionality can be built by rapid prototyping techniques [10].

The activities will broadly impact research communities through the dissemination of powerful and commoditized tools. BcLOV4 is a foundational technology from which others can build light-activated proteins of signaling function-of-choice. Its single-component operation is experimentally simple because only one transgene needs to be delivered and visualized. The application of the Rho-family tools created will improve understanding of how cells dynamically regulate their cytoskeleton in cell motility and development.  The OSP was designed to meet important biotechnological needs of under-resourced and educational settings. All resources created have been disseminated by Addgene (DNA plasmids) or Github (files, schematics, and assembly/application instructions) for community benefit. 

Representative publications:

(1) Glantz, S.T., et al., Directly light-regulated binding of RGS-LOV photoreceptors to anionic membrane phospholipids, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences USA (2018) 115 (33) E7720-E7727
(2) Glantz, S.T.*, Berlew, E.E.*, and Chow, B.Y., Synthetic cell-like membrane interfaces for probing dynamic protein-lipid interactions, Methods in Enzymology (2019) 622, 249-270 (* equal contributions)
(3) Hannanta-anan, P., Glantz, S.T., and Chow, B.Y., Optically inducible membrane recruitment and signaling systems, Current Opinion in Structural Biology (2019) 57, 84-92
(4) Berlew, E.E., et al., Designing single-component optogenetic membrane recruitment systems: the Rho-family GTPase signaling toolbox, ACS Synthetic Biology (2022), 11, 515-521
(5) Berlew, E.E., et al., Single-component optogenetic tools for inducible RhoA GTPase signaling, Advanced Biology (2021), e2100810
(6) Berlew, E.E., et al., Optogenetic Rac1 engineered from membrane lipid-binding RGS-LOV for inducible lamellipodia formation, Photochemical and Photobiological Sciences (2020) 19, 353-361
(7) Benman, W., et al., Temperature-responsive optogenetic probes of cell signaling, Nature Chemical Biology (2022), 18, 152-160
(8) Kuznetsov, I.A., et al., Computational framework for single-cell spatiotemporal dynamics of optogenetic membrane recruitment, Cell Reports Methods, (2022), accepted
(9) Szymula, K.P.*, Magaraci, M.S.*, et al., An open-source plate reader, Biochemistry (2019) 58(6), 468-473 (* equal contributions)
(10) Example Features: Automated Science on a Shoestring, Nature (2019), 569, pp. 587-588; Building a DIY Plate Reader, C&EN (2019) 97(2), p. 8
